modules.title: Primer to Climate Scenarios
modules.description: This interactive primer gives an introduction to what climate change scenarios are and how they are connected to socioeconomics, energy & land use, emissions, climate change and climate impacts.
modules.keywords: projection pathway ssp socioeconomic emissions concentration climate change impact mitigation adaptation integrated iam integrated assessment model
modules.subtitle: Learn module

modules.title: Extreme Events
modules.description: Climate change makes extreme events more frequent and more severe. This module investigates how exposure to crop failures, river floods, tropical cyclones, heatwaves, wildfires, and droughts changes with rising temperature levels.
sources: Lange, S., J. Volkholz, T. Geiger, F. Zhao, I. Vega, T. Veldkamp, C.P.O. Reyer, et al., (2020). Projecting exposure to extreme climate impact events across six event categories and three spatial scales

Klein Goldewijk, K., Beusen, A., Doelman, J., & Stehfest, E. (2017). Anthropogenic land use estimates for the Holocene – HYDE 3.2. Earth System Science Data, 9 (2), 927–953. doi: 10.5194/essd-9-927-2017

Scussolini, P., Aerts, J. C. J. H., Jongman, B., Bouwer, L. M., Winsemius, H. C., deMoel,H., & Ward, P. J. (2016). FLOPROS: an evolving global database of flood protectionstandards.Natural Hazards and Earth System Sciences,16(5), 1049–1061. doi:10.5194/nhess-16-1049-2016
modules.subtitle: Learn module

modules.title: Transition Risks – Preamble
modules.description: The transition towards a low carbon future requires large changes in the production, conversion and use of energy. This is the preamble to our three modules, that guide you through the main risks related to this transition.
modules.subtitle: Learn module

modules.title: End-Use Risks
modules.description: The end-use sector goes through a transition from carbon-emitting fuels towards cleaner fuels that don’t emit CO2. In this module we explore the risks and opportunities that result from this shift.
modules.keywords: end-use sector electricity finance investments risks economy transition
sources: UNEP, FI. (2018): Extending our horizons: Assessing credit risk and opportunity in a changing climate. Part I: Transition-Related Risks and Opportunities (2018).
modules.subtitle: Learn module

modules.title: Investment Opportunities and Alignment
modules.description: What are near-time investment requirements for meeting stringent climate targets in a low carbon world?
sources: Andrijevic, M., et al. (2020): “COVID-19 recovery funds dwarf clean energy investment needs.” Science 16 Oct 2020: Vol. 370, Issue 6514, pp. 298-300.
Bertram, C. et al. (2018): “Targeted Policies Can Compensate Most of the Increased Sustainability Risks in 1.5 °C Mitigation Scenarios.” Environmental Research Letters 13, no. 6: 064038.
BP (2020), Statistical Review of World Energy
Grubler, A. et al. (June 2018): “A Low Energy Demand Scenario for Meeting the 1.5 °C Target and Sustainable Development Goals without Negative Emission Technologies.” Nature Energy 3, no. 6: 515–27.
IEA (2020), World Energy Investment 2020, IEA, Paris

McCollum, D. L. et al. (2018): “Energy investment needs for fulfilling the Paris Agreement and achieving the Sustainable Development Goals.” Nature Energy, 3(7), 589–599.
modules.subtitle: Learn module

modules.title: The Role of Land for Food Production and Climate Protection
modules.description: Current land-use practices accelerate climate change. Mitigation strategies like afforestation and BECCS increase the demand for land, which puts food security and biodiversity at risk. Is it possible to reach the Paris Agreement goals without major trade-offs?
modules.keywords: land land-use transition sustainable sustability SDG food trade-off degradation desertification biodiversity
modules.subtitle: Learn module

modules.title: Learn Module of Co-Production Techniques
modules.description: In this module, we illustrate how to use co-production techniques to start or develop adaptation planning given different stages of the policy cycle.
modules.subtitle: Learn module

modules.title: A River of Information for Adaptation
modules.description: In this module, we illustrate how co-production techniques can be applied in combination with socioeconomic and impact scenarios to develop adaptation pathways for a climate robust and CO₂-neutral landscape. We demonstrate this process with the case study of the Dutch Overijsselse Vecht.
sources: Lotte de Jong (2020): Fuzzy Cognitive Maps for the Overijsselse Vecht
Simona Pedde & Lotte de Jong (2020): Vision scoring
modules.subtitle: Learn module

modules.title: Co-Producing Multi-Scale Scenarios for Adaptation
modules.description: In this module, we show how co-production techniques can be applied to developing socio-economic scenarios and adaptation options and strategies in sub-global impact, adaptation, and vulnerability studies. We demonstrate this process in a case study focused on Kenya.
sources: Sara Talebian, Henrik Carlsen (2020): Case study results, adaptation options
Sara Talebian, Henrik Carlsen (2020): Case study results, future cross-border climate impacts
Sara Talebian, Henrik Carlsen (2020): Case study results, future socioeconomic drivers, and states
modules.subtitle: Learn module

modules.title: Net-Zero Pathways for Industrialized Countries
modules.description: Industrialized countries need to move towards net-zero CO2 emissions by 2050. But, how can they achieve this? Here, we show simulation results that outline possible mitigation pathways towards net-zero CO2 emissions by 2050 for the EU, Japan, Australia and the US.
modules.portalDescription: Industrialized countries increasingly take up the target to reach net zero emissions by mid century. This is motivated by the finding of the IPCC that limiting warming to 1.5°C with no or low overshoot suggests net global CO2 emissions to become zero by mid century.
sources: Schreyer, F., Luderer, G., Rodrigues, R., Pietzcker, R. C., Baumstark, L., Sugiyama, M., Brecha, R. J., & Ueckerdt, F. (2020). Common but differentiated leadership: Strategies and challenges for carbon neutrality by 2050 across industrialized economies. Environmental Research Letters, 15(11), 114016.
modules.subtitle: Learn module

modules.title: Fossil Fuels Risks
modules.description: Our society is currently relying heavily on fossil fuels to provide energy to our industries, keep our homes at comfortable temperatures and move goods and persons around the globe. In this module we show the risks associated with investing in the fossil fuel sector to explain why investors should consider climate policy in their decisions.
modules.keywords: transition fossil fuels coal gas oil finance
sources: McCollum, D. L. et al. (2018): Energy investment needs for fulfilling the Paris Agreement and achieving the Sustainable Development Goals. Nature Energy, 3(7), 589–599.

Rogelj, J.et al. (2018): Mitigation pathways compatible with 1.5°C in the context of sustainable development. In Special Report on the impacts of global warming of 1.5 °C. Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.
modules.subtitle: Learn module

modules.title: Power Sector Risks
modules.description: In this module we explore the risks and opportunities that result from the decarbonization of the power sector and we explain why investors should take climate policy into account in their decision-making. We will explore the changes in electricity production and revenue, the changing risk structure of the power sector, the risk of fuel costs and emission costs, and the need for clean investments.
modules.keywords: power sector electricity finance investments risks economy transition
sources: UNEP, FI. (2018): Extending our horizons: Assessing credit risk and opportunity in a changing climate. Part I: Transition-Related Risks and Opportunities (2018).
modules.subtitle: Learn module

modules.title: Towards an Electric Future
modules.description: We cannot predict the future, but we can create different plausible scenarios of how a future decarbonization pathway could look like. In this module you will be introduced to the concept of Electrification and to the broad strategy to go Carbon Neutral by reducing emissions.
modules.portalDescription: A portfolio of measures in all sectors and regions are needed, fundamentally transforming the way we use energy and land.
sources: Hoesly, R. M. et al. (2018): Historical (1750–2014) anthropogenic emissions of reactive gases and aerosols from the Community Emissions Data System (CEDS), Geosci. Model Dev., 11, 369–408
IEA. (2017). Extended world energy balances [(Database)]. IEA World Energy Statistics and Balances.
Luderer, G. et al.(2020, May 8). REMIND - REgional Model of INvestments and Development. Zenodo.

modules.title: Closing the Emissions Gap
modules.description: This module explores how current decarbonization plans until 2030 relate to the long-term targets of the Paris Agreement.
modules.keywords: decarbonization plan paris agreement target emission gap carbon budget temperature stranded assets land use investment cost-effective policies policy mitigation technology cdr carbon dioxide removal short term long bridge scenario
modules.portalDescription: Current climate action plans are not aligned with the Paris climate goals. There is a gap between what those plans would deliver by 2030 and what a continuous reduction to net zero CO2 emissions by mid century would require. An immediate concern for climate policy worldwide is how to bridge this emissions gap.
sources: Kriegler, Elmar; et al. (2018): Short term policies to keep the door open for Paris climate goals
Luderer, Gunnar; et al. (2018): Residual fossil CO2 emissions in 1.5–2 °C pathways
Rogelj, J., et al. (2015): Energy system transformations for limiting end-of-century warming to below 1.5 °C.
Bloomberg New Energy Finance (2020): “Clean Energy Investment Trends 2019”

modules.title: A Brief History of CO₂ Emissions
modules.description: Greenhouse gas emissions are one of the driving forces behind climate change. In our short film “A Brief History of CO2 Emissions”, we visualize the geographic distribution and the historic dimension of carbon dioxide emissions.
